marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Joel Hubbard was a resident of Republican Grove, Halifax County, Virginia.

Letter to Joel Hubbard from Eli Ball concerning the work of the General Association of Virginia in gathering information about Baptist churches in the state; a personal letter from Hubbard's cousin, Jesse E. Adams; and letters concerning financial matters and the repayment of money which Hubbard had loaned.
Solomon Howe was a resident of New Salem (Franklin County), Massachusetts.

Family correspondence of Solomon Howe and his wife, Mary, and their children. Included are letters, 1819, from Jebediah Howe, concerning his stereotype foundry in New York City; letters, 1819-1821, from Milton Howe, who conducted a school in Richmond County, Va., giving some description of the country and his impressions of the people; letters from Celia Babbett, describing a journey to Orangeville, N.Y., and customs in western New York; and miscellaneous letters concerning New Englanders' reactions to the South, the depression following the panic of 1819, crops, commodity prices, and family matters.
David Howell was a resident of Charlestown, Jefferson County, Virginia.

Correspondence between David Howell and his wife Hannah, and Howell's father's family in Clark County, Ohio, discussing family matters with references to commodity prices, a smallpox epidemic in Wheeling, Virginia (now West Virginia), and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1829; the burning of Bushrod Washington's house; the death of President William Henry Harrison; and an abolitionist debate in Ohio.
Luther Howe was a plantation owner and brick plant operator in New Orleans, Louisiana.
Bill of sale by the heirs of Luther Howe for his land, slaves, and a brick plant which he had operated in partnership with François Xavier Martin.
A. Hubbell was a resident of New York.
Business correspondence and promissory notes of Hubbell and E. Curran.
Walter Hubbell was a resident of Canandaigua, New York.
Letter from Walter Hubbell to his wife describing his trip to Detroit through Lake Ontario and Lake Erie.
Horatio Hubbell was a lawyer, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Miscellaneous papers of Hubbell, including letters from Samuel F.B. Morse regarding Hubbell's claim to priority in the suggestion of a trans-Atlantic telegraph cable.
Thomas C. Hoyt was Captain of the barque, "Arthur;" from Beverly (Essex County), Massachusetts.

Papers of Thomas C. and Isaiah F. Hoyt, including letters to T.C. Hoyt's family describing his voyages to Africa, 1847; papers dealing with the pepper trade off the coast of Sumatra, including routes, prices for raw pepper, letters of credit, and invoices of the cargo carried to Sumatra for trade. Also includes papers dealing with the New England Shoe and Leather Association, of which T.C.'s nephew, Charles Hoyt, was president. Isaiah Hoyt's papers are principally concerned with his efforts to obtain money owed him for his service in the Union Army, in the 32nd Massachusetts Volunteers. Scattered references concern his business affairs as secretary of the Union Flax Mills in Chicago and as a deputy collector of Internal Revenue in Illinois.
New England Shoe and Leather Association.
New England Shoe and Leather Association.
Tazewell M. Howard was a physician, from Campbelltown (Fulton County), Georgia.

Letters from Howard to a younger brother who was a medical student in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, containing brief references to the Know-Nothing Party, secession, and a rumor that Governor Henry A. Wise of Virginia had been murdered by abolitionists; and Civil War letters of Dr. T.H. Howard and H.L. Honnell from Georgia, Kentucky and Mississippi.
Edmund Wilcox Hubard (1806-1878) was a planter and member of United States Congress, 1841-1847, of Virginia.
Papers of Edmund W. Hubard referring to the appointment of a manager of the public schools and to physicians practicing in Richmond.
The Howerton family resided in Roxboro, Person County, North Carolina.

Letters from Sarah Lansdell Howerton to her husband Richard Thomas Howerton, describing in detail an illness which prevents her from returning home; four clippings, including an obituary for Kate Boshamer Howerton; Kate Boshamer's autograph album; and a tribute to Stonewall Jackson addressed to the editor of the WHIG, Richmond, June 13, 1862.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
Joshua A. Howell was a Colonel, 85th Pennsylvania Regiment, U.S.A., stationed in South Carolina and Virginia.

Miscellaneous papers of Howell, including ordnance, morning, and quartermaster reports; special orders concerning Howell's commands at Hilton Head, S.C., and Gloucester Point, Va.; letter from Howell discussing a battle near Franklin, Va.; letter from General Alfred Howe Terry to Katherine W. Howell concerning her husband's injuries and promotion to brigadier general; and letters requesting passes for Benjamin P. Howell, in order that he can recover his brother's body.
Wade H. Hubbard was a private in the Confederate Army stationed near Wilmington, North Carolina; from Anson County, North Carolina.
Civil War correspondence of Wade H. Hubbard showing his attitude toward the war, describing the battle of Fort Fisher, 1865, and discussing farm conditions at home.
Samuel Gridley Howe was a physician, reformer, and husband of Julia Ward Howe.
Note by Samuel Gridley Howe inviting a visit by a friend. It is written on the reverse side of a fragment of a 1868 letter written by an unknown author.
Oliver Otis Howard was Commissioner of the Freedmen's Bureau, 1865-1872.

The collection consists of two letters, both written while Howard was Commissioner of the Freedmen's Bureau. The first letter (April 6, 1870) is from Brigadier-General George Williamson Balloch, Chief Disbursing Officer of the Bureau to Adelbert Ames, U.S. Senator from Miss., informing Ames that he did not need any more paid bounty agents in Miss. The second letter (June 21, 1870) is from Martin Wilson Philips to Howard. (Philips is editor-in-chief of THE SOUTHERN FARMER.) He writes on behalf of four young men in his employment. The men had purchased land with unclear titles as a result of that land having been sold under a special war tax and bought by the federal government. Most of Philips's letter, however, is devoted to his views on Reconstruction.
Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands.
Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands.
Elbert Hubbard was an author and lecturer, proprietor of the Roycroft Shop, publisher of de luxe editions of the classics, located in East Aurora, New York.
Eight letters from Hubbard and one from his wife Alice to George Bicknell primarily relating to Roycroft publications and to Hubbard's lecturing activities.
